newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil analysts said Licht sugar figure too high.
newsitem.headline: Brazil analysts said Licht sugar figure too high.

text.p: An estimate by German statistician F.O. Licht of a 1996/97 Brazilian sugar crop of 15.02 million tonnes is seen as excessive by Brazilian analysts and industry associations.

"This is too high and over-exaggerated. Our most optimistic figure is for a little over 13 million tonnes," said Jose Pilon, president of the Sao Paulo Sugar and Alcohol Industries Association (AIAA).
It was also very difficult at this stage to give an accurate crop estimate given that the harvest in the north/northeast had only really just gotten underway.
"Also this year's harvest in the center-south started earlier than normal so if it finishes earlier than usual, you have one estimate," Pilon said.
"But if it carries on right to the end of the normal harvesting period, then you have another scenario completely," he added.
The country's harvest in the center-south, the main producing region, traditionally runs from May to November.
This year however it began in some places as early as April 15 leading to differences as to exactly how this year's crop is running compared with that of 1995/96.

The AIAA is still using the official starting point as May 1, so that by September 15, the center-south crop totalled 7.12 million tonnes, up 16 percent from the same date last year according to the AIAA.

However analyst Aloisio Sotero of independent consultants DataNet-Agricommodities is comparing fortnightly periods rather than dates and so sees the crop as showing a much more subdued increase over the corresponding period last season.
As a result Sotero also sees Licht's forecast as too high.
"This is an over-estimate which reflects the view of producers," Sotero said.

"Producers have said this crop will be 10 percent more than last year just to persuade the government to release remaining export quotas," he said, pointing out the forecast was roughly 10 percent up on Licht's 1995/96 figure of 13.64 million tonnes.
Sotero is planning to release his own estimate of the crop later this week.
The AIAA also does not agree with Licht figure for the 1995/96 crop which it puts at around 12.4 million tonnes.
The government crop plan has allowed for output of 13.68 million tonnes of sugar, of which 5.2 million tonnes may in theory be exported free of export tax.

So far however the government has only authorised 80 percent of this total and traders and producers in the center-south say they are now waiting for the release of the remaining 20 percent before being able to make further overseas sales.
The head of the primary commodities department at the Industry and Commerce Ministry, Mauricio Assis, said that the authorisation was "in the final stages of technical analysis.
Assis declined to comment on the Licht estimate.
-- Caroline Bulloch, Rio de Janeiro newsroom, 5521 5074151
